div.p: SUB-DEACON, an inferior miniſter, who anciently attended at the altar, prepared the ſacred vessels, delivered them to the deacons in time of divine ſervice, attended the doors of the church during communion-ſervice, went on the the biſhop’s embaſſies with his letters or messages to foreign churches, and was invested with the firſt of the holy orders. They were ſo ſubordinate to the ſuperior rulers of the church, that, by a canon of the council of Laodicea, they were forbidden to sit in the preſence of a deacon without his leave. According to the canons, a perſon muſt be twenty two years of age to be promoted to the order of ſubdeacon. See Deacon.
